thread.title: Five moments that mattered from Jays’ Game 2 in Kansas City
thread.title_full: Five moments that mattered from Blue Jays’ Game 2 in Kansas City | Toronto Star

author: Brendan Kennedy
title: Five moments that mattered from Jays’ Game 2 in Kansas City
text:
KANSAS CITY—Everything unraveled for David Price and the Blue Jays in the seventh inning on Saturday as they watched their 3-0 lead evaporate over the course of just five batters.
With Price dominant through the first six frames, the Royals took advantage of a gaffe by Ryan Goins, who watched a routine pop-up drop in front of him, to ignite a five-run rally.
Now, the Jays head back to Toronto with a familiar 2-0 series deficit, hoping they can once again climb out of an early hole.
Martin stymied
With runners at first and second and just one out in the second inning, Russell Martin lined Yordano Ventura’s 97-m.p.h. fastball up the middle but was robbed by a diving Alcides Escobar, the Royals shortstop, who stole a would-be RBI from Martin and flipped the ball to Ben Zobrist at second base to double off Edwin Encarnacion and end the inning.
The speed of the ball off Martin’s bat was 111 m.p.h., his hardest hit all season, and it could have broken the game open for the Jays early. Instead, Ventura escaped unscathed. The Jays would take a 1-0 lead the next inning when Kevin Pillar and Ryan Goins hit back-to-back doubles, but Martin’s out still felt like a missed opportunity.
Tulo snaps slump
Jays shortstop Troy Tulowitzki, who came back early from his cracked shoulder blade to join the team in time for the post-season, is clearly not 100 per cent. While he continues to play stellar defence, he is not himself at the plate. But he had a good day on Saturday, going 2-for-2 with an RBI double to snap a 0-for-13 hitless streak. He still only has four hits in the post-season, with the other two coming in Game 3 of the ALDS against the Texas Rangers, when he hit the game-breaking, three-run homer.
“I’m just battling, just trying to do what I can,” he said after Saturday’s game.
Price strikes out side
For six innings on Saturday, Price pitched an absolute gem. He set a Jays’ record by retiring 18 consecutive batters after a leadoff single by Escobar in the first. He relentlessly pounded the zone and worked efficiently, needing just 66 pitches through his first 18 outs. He may have been at his best in the sixth, when he threw up an authoritative zero after the Jays had added to their lead in the top half of the inning by striking out the side. He mixed and matched all of his pitches — alternating his 79-m.p.h. curveball, 91-m.p.h. cutter, 85-m.p.h. changeup and 94-m.p.h. fastball — to keep Alex Gordon, Alex Rios and Alcides Escobar guessing.
The Sky falls
Price was cruising, unhittable, until his former teammate, Ben Zobrist, led off the seventh inning with a harmless-looking pop-up to shallow right field. Goins appeared to have a beat on it, repeatedly waving off right fielder Jose Bautista. But at the last second, Goins gave way. He said later that he thought he heard an “I got it,” perhaps amid the deafening crowd noise.
There was little hint then — given how well Price was pitching — that the gaffe would become a turning point. But with that crack in the door the Royals barged through, rallying for five runs to take the lead.
“The blame should go on me today,” Goins said. “I gave them that play to start that rally.”
Game-over Gordon
Alex Gordon, arguably the Royals’ best all-around player who is batting in the eighth spot in the batting order after spending nearly two months on the disabled list, had the biggest hit of the Royals’ seventh-inning rally.
For Price, who had already given up three runs on four hits, the full-count fastball he left over the middle of the plate to Gordon was the pitch he would most like to have back. Gordon lined it into the gap to score the winning run. Afterward, Gordon said the dropped fly ball was the opening they needed against Price.
“I felt like we needed to catch a break, and Zobrist’s ball there got things going. And once this lineup gets moving, it’s one guy after another. It was a big seventh inning.”
